text: These are the names of the sons of Israel who came to Egypt with Jacob, each with his household:
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dan and Naphtali, Gad and Asher.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of people born to Jacob was seventy. (Joseph was already in Egypt.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph died, and all his brothers, and that whole generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Israelites were fruitful and prolific; they multiplied and grew exceedingly strong, so that the land was filled with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now a new king arose over Egypt who did not know Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his people, “Look, the Israelite people are more numerous and more powerful than we.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, let us deal shrewdly with them, or they will increase and, in the event of war, join our enemies and fight against us and escape from the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore they set taskmasters over them to oppress them with forced labor. They built supply cities, Pithom and Rameses, for Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the more they were oppressed, the more they multiplied and spread, so that the Egyptians came to dread the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians subjected the Israelites to hard servitude
speaker: Narrator

text: and made their lives bitter with hard servitude in mortar and bricks and in every kind of field labor. They were ruthless in all the tasks that they imposed on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Egypt said to the Hebrew midwives, one of whom was named Shiphrah and the other Puah,
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you act as midwives to the Hebrew women and see them on the birthstool, if it is a son, kill him, but if it is a daughter, she shall live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the midwives feared God; they did not do as the king of Egypt commanded them, but they let the boys live.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Egypt summoned the midwives and said to them, “Why have you done this and allowed the boys to live?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The midwives said to Pharaoh, “Because the Hebrew women are not like the Egyptian women, for they are vigorous and give birth before the midwife comes to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So God dealt well with the midwives, and the people multiplied and became very strong.
speaker: Narrator

text: And because the midwives feared God, he gave them families.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh commanded all his people, “Every son that is born to the Hebrews you shall throw into the Nile, but you shall let every daughter live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now a man from the house of Levi went and married a Levite woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman conceived and bore a son, and when she saw that he was a fine baby, she hid him three months.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she could hide him no longer she got a papyrus basket for him and plastered it with bitumen and pitch; she put the child in it and placed it among the reeds on the bank of the river.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sister stood at a distance, to see what would happen to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The daughter of Pharaoh came down to bathe at the river, while her attendants walked beside the river. She saw the basket among the reeds and sent her maid to bring it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she opened it, she saw the child. He was crying, and she took pity on him. “This must be one of the Hebrews’ children,” she said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his sister said to Pharaoh’s daughter, “Shall I go and get you a nurse from the Hebrew women to nurse the child for you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, “Yes.” So the girl went and called the child’s mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, “Take this child and nurse it for me, and I will give you your wages.” So the woman took the child and nursed it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the child grew up, she brought him to Pharaoh’s daughter, and he became her son. She named him Moses, “because,” she said, “I drew him out of the water.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day after Moses had grown up, he went out to his people and saw their forced labor. He saw an Egyptian beating a Hebrew, one of his own people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked this way and that, and seeing no one he killed the Egyptian and hid him in the sand.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he went out the next day, he saw two Hebrews fighting, and he said to the one who was in the wrong, “Why do you strike your fellow Hebrew?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He answered, “Who made you a ruler and judge over us? Do you mean to kill me as you killed the Egyptian?” Then Moses was afraid and thought, “Surely the thing is known.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Pharaoh heard of it, he sought to kill Moses.
So Moses fled from Pharaoh. He settled in the land of Midian and sat down by a well.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest of Midian had seven daughters. They came to draw water and filled the troughs to water their father’s flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: But some shepherds came and drove them away. Moses got up and came to their defense and watered their flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they returned to their father Reuel, he said, “How is it that you have come back so soon today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “An Egyptian helped us against the shepherds; he even drew water for us and watered the flock.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his daughters, “Where is he? Why did you leave the man? Invite him to share a meal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses agreed to stay with the man, and he gave Moses his daughter Zipporah in marriage.
speaker: Narrator

text: She bore a son, and he named him Gershom, for he said, “I have been an alien residing in a foreign land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After a long time the king of Egypt died. The Israelites groaned under their slavery and cried out. Their cry for help rose up to God from their slavery.
speaker: Narrator

text: God heard their groaning, and God remembered his covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: God looked upon the Israelites, and God took notice of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was keeping the flock of his father-in-law Jethro, the priest of Midian; he led his flock beyond the wilderness and came to Mount Horeb, the mountain of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: There the angel of the Lord appeared to him in a flame of fire out of a bush; he looked, and the bush was blazing, yet it was not consumed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said, “I must turn aside and look at this great sight and see why the bush is not burned up.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord saw that he had turned aside to see, God called to him out of the bush, “Moses, Moses!” And he said, “Here I am.”
speaker: God

text: Then he said, “Come no closer! Remove the sandals from your feet, for the place on which you are standing is holy ground.”
speaker: God

text: He said further, “I am the God of your father, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.” And Moses hid his face, for he was afraid to look at God.
speaker: God

text: Then the Lord said, “I have observed the misery of my people who are in Egypt; I have heard their cry on account of their taskmasters. Indeed, I know their sufferings,
speaker: God

text: and I have come down to deliver them from the Egyptians and to bring them up out of that land to a good and spacious land, to a land flowing with milk and honey, to the country of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites.
speaker: God

text: The cry of the Israelites has now come to me; I have also seen how the Egyptians oppress them.
speaker: God

text: Now go, I am sending you to Pharaoh to bring my people, the Israelites, out of Egypt.”
speaker: God

text: But Moses said to God, “Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh and bring the Israelites out of Egypt?”
speaker: God

text: He said, “I will be with you, and this shall be the sign for you that it is I who sent you: when you have brought the people out of Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain.”
speaker: God

text: But Moses said to God, “If I come to the Israelites and say to them, ‘The God of your ancestors has sent me to you,’ and they ask me, ‘What is his name?’ what shall I say to them?”
speaker: God

text: God said to Moses, “I am who I am.” He said further, “Thus you shall say to the Israelites, ‘I am has sent me to you.’ ”
speaker: God

text:
God also said to Moses, “Thus you shall say to the Israelites, ‘The Lord, the God of your ancestors, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has sent me to you’:
This is my name forever,
and this my title for all generations.
speaker: God

text: “Go and assemble the elders of Israel and say to them, ‘The Lord, the God of your ancestors, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, has appeared to me, saying: I have given heed to you and to what has been done to you in Egypt.
speaker: God

text: I declare that I will bring you up out of the misery of Egypt, to the land of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites, a land flowing with milk and honey.’
speaker: God

text: They will listen to your voice, and you and the elders of Israel shall go to the king of Egypt and say to him, ‘The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, has met with us; let us now go a three days’ journey into the wilderness, so that we may sacrifice to the Lord our God.’
speaker: God

text: I know, however, that the king of Egypt will not let you go except by a mighty hand.
speaker: God

text: So I will stretch out my hand and strike Egypt with all my wonders that I will perform in it; after that he will let you go.
speaker: God

text: I will bring this people into such favor with the Egyptians that, when you go, you will not go empty-handed;
speaker: God

text: each woman shall ask her neighbor and any woman living in the neighbor’s house for jewelry of silver and of gold and clothing, and you shall put them on your sons and on your daughters; so you shall plunder the Egyptians.”
speaker: God

text: Then Moses answered, “But look, they may not believe me or listen to me but say, ‘The Lord did not appear to you.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to him, “What is that in your hand?” He said, “A staff.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “Throw it on the ground.” So he threw the staff on the ground, and it became a snake, and Moses drew back from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Reach out your hand and seize it by the tail”—so he reached out his hand and grasped it, and it became a staff in his hand—
speaker: Narrator

text: “so that they may believe that the Lord, the God of their ancestors, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has appeared to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Again, the Lord said to him, “Put your hand inside your cloak.” He put his hand into his cloak, and when he took it out, his hand was diseased, as white as snow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Put your hand back into your cloak”—so he put his hand back into his cloak, and when he took it out, it was restored like the rest of his body—
speaker: Narrator

text: “If they will not believe you or heed the first sign, they may believe the second sign.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they will not believe even these two signs or listen to you, you shall take some water from the Nile and pour it on the dry ground, and the water that you shall take from the Nile will become blood on the dry ground.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said to the Lord, “O my Lord, I have never been eloquent, neither in the past nor even now that you have spoken to your servant, but I am slow of speech and slow of tongue.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to him, “Who gives speech to mortals? Who makes them mute or deaf, seeing or blind? Is it not I, the Lord?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now go, and I will be with your mouth and teach you what you are to speak.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said, “O my Lord, please send someone else.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the anger of the Lord was kindled against Moses, and he said, “What of your brother Aaron, the Levite? I know that he can speak well; even now he is coming out to meet you, and when he sees you his heart will be glad.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall speak to him and put the words in his mouth, and I will be with your mouth and with his mouth and will teach you what you shall do.
speaker: Narrator

text: He indeed shall speak for you to the people; he shall serve as a mouth for you, and you shall serve as God for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take in your hand this staff, with which you shall perform the signs.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses went back to his father-in-law Jethro and said to him, “Please let me go back to my own people in Egypt and see whether they are still living.” And Jethro said to Moses, “Go in peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses in Midian, “Go back to Egypt, for all those who were seeking your life are dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses took his wife and his sons, put them on a donkey, and went back to the land of Egypt, and Moses carried the staff of God in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said to Moses, “When you go back to Egypt, see that you perform before Pharaoh all the wonders that I have put in your power, but I will harden his heart, so that he will not let the people go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you shall say to Pharaoh, ‘Thus says the Lord: Israel is my firstborn son.
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to you, “Let my son go that he may serve me.” But you refused to let him go; now I will kill your firstborn son.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the way, at a place where they spent the night, the Lord met him and tried to kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Zipporah took a flint and cut off her son’s foreskin, touched his feet with it, and said, “Truly you are a bridegroom of blood to me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he let him alone. It was then that she said “a bridegroom of blood,” because of the circumcision.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Aaron, “Go into the wilderness to meet Moses.” So he went, and he met him at the mountain of God and kissed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told Aaron all the words of the Lord with which he had sent him and all the signs with which he had charged him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron went and assembled all the elders of the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron spoke all the words that the Lord had spoken to Moses and performed the signs in the sight of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people believed, and when they heard that the Lord had given heed to the Israelites and that he had seen their misery, they bowed down and worshiped.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and said, “Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: Let my people go, so that they may celebrate a festival to me in the wilderness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Pharaoh said, “Who is the Lord, that I should listen to him and let Israel go? I do not know the Lord, and I will not let Israel go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said, “The God of the Hebrews has revealed himself to us; let us go a three days’ journey into the wilderness to sacrifice to the Lord our God, or he will fall upon us with pestilence or sword.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king of Egypt said to them, “Moses and Aaron, why are you taking the people away from their work? Get to your labors!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh continued, “Now they are more numerous than the people of the land and yet you want them to stop laboring!”
speaker: Narrator

text: That same day Pharaoh commanded the taskmasters of the people, as well as their supervisors,
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall no longer give the people straw to make bricks, as before; let them go and gather straw for themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you shall require of them the same quantity of bricks as they have made previously; do not diminish it, for they are lazy; that is why they cry, ‘Let us go and sacrifice to our God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Let heavier work be laid on them; then they will pay attention to it and not to deceptive words.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the taskmasters and the supervisors of the people went out and said to the people, “Thus says Pharaoh: I will not give you straw.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go and get straw yourselves, wherever you can find it, but your work will not be lessened in the least.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people scattered throughout the land of Egypt to gather stubble for straw.
speaker: Narrator

text: The taskmasters urged them on, saying, “Complete your work, the same daily assignment as when you were given straw.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Israelite supervisors whom Pharaoh’s taskmasters had set over them were beaten and were asked, “Why did you not finish the required quantity of bricks yesterday and today, as you did before?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Israelite supervisors came to Pharaoh and cried, “Why do you treat your servants like this?
speaker: Narrator

text: No straw is given to your servants, yet they say to us, ‘Make bricks!’ Look how your servants are beaten! But the fault is with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “You are lazy, lazy; that is why you say, ‘Let us go and sacrifice to the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Go now and work, for no straw shall be given you, but you shall still deliver the same number of bricks.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelite supervisors saw that they were in trouble when they were told, “You shall not lessen your daily number of bricks.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As they left Pharaoh, they came upon Moses and Aaron, who were waiting to meet them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to them, “The Lord look upon you and judge! You have brought us into bad odor with Pharaoh and his officials and have put a sword in their hand to kill us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses turned to the Lord and said, “O my Lord, why have you mistreated this people? Why did you ever send me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Since I first came to Pharaoh to speak in your name, he has mistreated this people, and you have done nothing at all to deliver your people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Now you shall see what I will do to Pharaoh: indeed, by a mighty hand he will let them go; by a mighty hand he will drive them out of his land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God also spoke to Moses and said to him, “I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I appeared to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob as God Almighty, but by my name ‘The Lord’ I did not make myself known to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also established my covenant with them, to give them the land of Canaan, the land in which they resided as aliens.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have also heard the groaning of the Israelites whom the Egyptians have enslaved, and I have remembered my covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say therefore to the Israelites: I am the Lord, and I will free you from the burdens of the Egyptians and deliver you from slavery to them. I will redeem you with an outstretched arm and with great acts of judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take you as my people, and I will be your God. You shall know that I am the Lord your God, who has freed you from the burdens of the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring you into the land that I swore to give to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob; I will give it to you for a possession. I am the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told this to the Israelites, but they would not listen to Moses, because of their broken spirit and their cruel slavery.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go and tell Pharaoh king of Egypt to let the Israelites go out of his land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses spoke to the Lord, “The Israelites have not listened to me; why should Pharaoh listen to me, poor speaker that I am?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron and gave them orders regarding the Israelites and Pharaoh king of Egypt, to free the Israelites from the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The following are the heads of their ancestral houses: the sons of Reuben, the firstborn of Israel: Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi; these are the families of Reuben.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Simeon: Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul, the son of a Canaanite woman; these are the families of Simeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The following are the names of the sons of Levi according to their genealogies: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari, and the length of Levi’s life was one hundred thirty-seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Gershon: Libni and Shimei, by their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Kohath: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel, and the length of Kohath’s life was one hundred thirty-three years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Merari: Mahli and Mushi. These are the families of the Levites according to their genealogies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amram married Jochebed his aunt, and she bore him Aaron and Moses, and the length of Amram’s life was one hundred thirty-seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Izhar: Korah, Nepheg, and Zichri.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Uzziel: Mishael, Elzaphan, and Sithri.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron married Elisheba, daughter of Amminadab and sister of Nahshon, and she bore him Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Korah: Assir, Elkanah, and Abiasaph; these are the families of the Korahites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron’s son Eleazar married one of the daughters of Putiel, and she bore him Phinehas. These are the heads of the ancestral houses of the Levites by their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was this same Aaron and Moses to whom the Lord said, “Bring the Israelites out of the land of Egypt, company by company.”
speaker: Narrator

text: It was they who spoke to Pharaoh king of Egypt to bring the Israelites out of Egypt, the same Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day when the Lord spoke to Moses in the land of Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord said to Moses, “I am the Lord; tell Pharaoh king of Egypt all that I am speaking to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said to the Lord, “Since I am a poor speaker, why should Pharaoh listen to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “See, I have made you like God to Pharaoh, and your brother Aaron shall be your prophet.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall speak all that I command you, and your brother Aaron shall tell Pharaoh to let the Israelites go out of his land.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will harden Pharaoh’s heart, and I will multiply my signs and wonders in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh does not listen to you, I will lay my hand upon Egypt and bring my people the Israelites, company by company, out of the land of Egypt by great acts of judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians shall know that I am the Lord when I stretch out my hand against Egypt and bring the Israelites out from among them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron did so; they did just as the Lord commanded them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was eighty years old and Aaron eighty-three when they spoke to Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “When Pharaoh says to you, ‘Perform a wonder,’ then you shall say to Aaron, ‘Take your staff and throw it down before Pharaoh, and it will become a snake.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and did as the Lord had commanded; Aaron threw down his staff before Pharaoh and his officials, and it became a snake.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh summoned the wise men and the sorcerers, and they also, the magicians of Egypt, did the same by their secret arts.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each one threw down his staff, and they became snakes, but Aaron’s staff swallowed up theirs.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, Pharaoh’s heart was hardened, and he would not listen to them, as the Lord had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Pharaoh’s heart is hardened; he refuses to let the people go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go to Pharaoh in the morning, as he is going out to the water; stand by at the bank of the Nile to meet him, and take in your hand the staff that was turned into a snake.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to him, ‘The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, sent me to you to say, “Let my people go, so that they may serve me in the wilderness.” But until now you have not listened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus says the Lord, “By this you shall know that I am the Lord.” See, with the staff that is in my hand I will strike the water that is in the Nile, and it shall be turned to blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fish in the river shall die, the river itself shall stink, and the Egyptians shall be unable to drink water from the Nile.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Say to Aaron: Take your staff and stretch out your hand over the waters of Egypt—over its rivers, its canals, and its ponds, and all its pools of water—so that they may become blood, and there shall be blood throughout the whole land of Egypt, even in vessels of wood and in vessels of stone.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron did just as the Lord commanded. In the sight of Pharaoh and of his officials he lifted up the staff and struck the water in the Nile; all the water in the river was turned into blood,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the fish in the river died. The river stank so that the Egyptians could not drink its water, and there was blood throughout the whole land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the magicians of Egypt did the same by their secret arts; so Pharaoh’s heart remained hardened, and he would not listen to them, as the Lord had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh turned and went into his house, and he did not take even this to heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the Egyptians had to dig along the Nile for water to drink, for they could not drink the water of the river.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seven days passed after the Lord had struck the Nile.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh and say to him, ‘Thus says the Lord: Let my people go, so that they may serve me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you refuse to let them go, I will plague your whole country with frogs.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Nile shall swarm with frogs; they shall come up into your palace, into your bedchamber and your bed, into the houses of your officials and of your people, and into your ovens and your kneading bowls.
speaker: Narrator

text: The frogs shall come up on you and on your people and on all your officials.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said to Moses, “Say to Aaron, ‘Stretch out your hand with your staff over the rivers, the canals, and the pools, and make frogs come up on the land of Egypt.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Aaron stretched out his hand over the waters of Egypt, and the frogs came up and covered the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the magicians did the same by their secret arts and brought frogs up on the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh called Moses and Aaron and said, “Pray to the Lord to take away the frogs from me and my people, and I will let the people go to sacrifice to the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Pharaoh, “Kindly tell me when I am to pray for you and for your officials and for your people, that the frogs may be removed from you and your houses and be left only in the Nile.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “Tomorrow.” Moses said, “As you say! So that you may know that there is no one like the Lord our God,
speaker: Narrator

text: the frogs shall leave you and your houses and your officials and your people; they shall be left only in the Nile.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron went out from Pharaoh, and Moses cried out to the Lord concerning the frogs that he had brought upon Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord did as Moses requested: the frogs died in the houses, the courtyards, and the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they gathered them together in heaps, and the land stank.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you lift up your staff and stretch out your hand over the sea and divide it, that the Israelites may go into the sea on dry ground.

text: Then I will harden the hearts of the Egyptians so that they will go in after them, and so I will gain glory for myself over Pharaoh and all his army, his chariots, and his chariot drivers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Egyptians shall know that I am the Lord, when I have gained glory for myself over Pharaoh, his chariots, and his chariot drivers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of God who was going before the Israelite army moved and went behind them, and the pillar of cloud moved from in front of them and took its place behind them.
speaker: Narrator

text: It came between the army of Egypt and the army of Israel. And so the cloud was there with the darkness, and it lit up the night; one did not come near the other all night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses stretched out his hand over the sea. The Lord drove the sea back by a strong east wind all night and turned the sea into dry land, and the waters were divided.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites went into the sea on dry ground, the waters forming a wall for them on their right and on their left.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians pursued and went into the sea after them, all of Pharaoh’s horses, chariots, and chariot drivers.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the morning watch the Lord, in the pillar of fire and cloud, looked down on the Egyptian army and threw the Egyptian army into a panic.
speaker: Narrator

text: He clogged their chariot wheels so that they turned with difficulty. The Egyptians said, “Let us flee from the Israelites, for the Lord is fighting for them against Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand over the sea, so that the water may come back upon the Egyptians, upon their chariots and chariot drivers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses stretched out his hand over the sea, and at dawn the sea returned to its normal depth. As the Egyptians fled before it, the Lord tossed the Egyptians into the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: The waters returned and covered the chariots and the chariot drivers, the entire army of Pharaoh that had followed them into the sea; not one of them remained.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Israelites walked on dry ground through the sea, the waters forming a wall for them on their right and on their left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus the Lord saved Israel that day from the Egyptians, and Israel saw the Egyptians dead on the seashore.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel saw the great work that the Lord did against the Egyptians. So the people feared the Lord and believed in the Lord and in his servant Moses.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
The Lord is a warrior;
    the Lord is his name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pharaoh’s chariots and his army he cast into the sea;
    his elite officers were sunk in the Red Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The floods covered them;
    they went down into the depths like a stone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your right hand, O Lord, glorious in power—
    your right hand, O Lord, shattered the enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the greatness of your majesty you overthrew your adversaries;
    you sent out your fury; it consumed them like stubble.
speaker: Narrator

You blew with your wind; the sea covered them;
    they sank like lead in the mighty waters.

text:
Who is like you, O Lord, among the gods?
    Who is like you, majestic in holiness,

You stretched out your right hand;

In your steadfast love you led the people whom you redeemed;

The peoples heard; they trembled;
    pangs seized the inhabitants of Philistia.

until your people, O Lord, passed by,

text: The Lord will reign forever and ever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the horses of Pharaoh with his chariots and his chariot drivers went into the sea, the Lord brought back the waters of the sea upon them, but the Israelites walked through the sea on dry ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the prophet Miriam, Aaron’s sister, took a tambourine in her hand, and all the women went out after her with tambourines and with dancing.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Then Moses ordered Israel to set out from the Red Sea, and they went into the wilderness of Shur. They went three days in the wilderness and found no water.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to Marah, they could not drink the water of Marah because it was bitter. That is why it was called Marah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the people complained against Moses, saying, “What shall we drink?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He cried out to the Lord, and the Lord showed him a piece of wood; he threw it into the water, and the water became sweet.
There the Lord made for them a statute and an ordinance, and there he put them to the test.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “If you will listen carefully to the voice of the Lord your God, and do what is right in his sight, and give heed to his commandments and keep all his statutes, I will not bring upon you any of the diseases that I brought upon the Egyptians, for I am the Lord who heals you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they came to Elim, where there were twelve springs of water and seventy palm trees, and they camped there by the water.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole congregation of the Israelites set out from Elim and came to the wilderness of Sin, which is between Elim and Sinai, on the fifteenth day of the second month after they had departed from the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole congregation of the Israelites complained against Moses and Aaron in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites said to them, “If only we had died by the hand of the Lord in the land of Egypt, when we sat by the pots of meat and ate our fill of bread, for you have brought us out into this wilderness to kill this whole assembly with hunger.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “I am going to rain bread from heaven for you, and each day the people shall go out and gather enough for that day. In that way I will test them, whether they will follow my instruction or not.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the sixth day, when they prepare what they bring in, it will be twice as much as they gather on other days.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron said to all the Israelites, “In the evening you shall know that it was the Lord who brought you out of the land of Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: and in the morning you shall see the glory of the Lord, because he has heard your complaining against the Lord. For what are we, that you complain against us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses said, “When the Lord gives you meat to eat in the evening and your fill of bread in the morning, because the Lord has heard the complaining that you utter against him—what are we? Your complaining is not against us but against the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to Aaron, “Say to the whole congregation of the Israelites: ‘Draw near to the Lord, for he has heard your complaining.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: And as Aaron spoke to the whole congregation of the Israelites, they looked toward the wilderness, and the glory of the Lord appeared in the cloud.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I have heard the complaining of the Israelites; say to them, ‘At twilight you shall eat meat, and in the morning you shall have your fill of bread; then you shall know that I am the Lord your God.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the evening quails came up and covered the camp, and in the morning there was a layer of dew around the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the layer of dew lifted, there on the surface of the wilderness was a fine flaky substance, as fine as frost on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Israelites saw it, they said to one another, “What is it?” For they did not know what it was. Moses said to them, “It is the bread that the Lord has given you to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord has commanded: Gather as much of it as each of you needs, an omer per person according to the number of persons, all providing for those in their own tents.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites did so, some gathering more, some less.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they measured it with an omer, those who gathered much had nothing over, and those who gathered little had no shortage; they gathered as much as each of them needed.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses said to them, “Let no one leave any of it over until morning.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they did not listen to Moses; some left part of it until morning, and it became wormy and rotten. And Moses was angry with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Morning by morning they gathered it, as much as each needed, but when the sun grew hot, it melted.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the sixth day they gathered twice as much food, two omers apiece. When all the leaders of the congregation came and told Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: he said to them, “This is what the Lord has commanded: Tomorrow is a day of solemn rest, a holy Sabbath to the Lord; bake what you want to bake and boil what you want to boil, and all that is left over put aside to be kept until morning.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they put it aside until morning, just as Moses commanded them, and it did not rot, and there were no maggots in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “Eat it today, for today is a Sabbath to the Lord; today you will not find it in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: Six days you shall gather it, but on the seventh day, which is a Sabbath, there will be none.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day some of the people went out to gather, and they found none.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “How long will you refuse to keep my commandments and instructions?
speaker: Narrator

text: See! The Lord has given you the Sabbath; therefore on the sixth day he gives you food for two days; each of you stay where you are; do not leave your place on the seventh day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people rested on the seventh day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites called it manna; it was like white coriander seed, and the taste of it was like wafers made with honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “This is what the Lord has commanded: Let an omer of it be kept throughout your generations in order that they may see the food with which I fed you in the wilderness when I brought you out of the land of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses said to Aaron, “Take a jar, and put an omer of manna in it, and place it before the Lord, to be kept throughout your generations.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as the Lord commanded Moses, so Aaron placed it before the covenant, for safekeeping.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites ate manna forty years, until they came to a habitable land; they ate manna, until they came to the border of the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: (An omer is a tenth of an ephah.)
speaker: Narrator

text: From the wilderness of Sin the whole congregation of the Israelites journeyed by stages, as the Lord commanded. They camped at Rephidim, but there was no water for the people to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people quarreled with Moses and said, “Give us water to drink.” Moses said to them, “Why do you quarrel with me? Why do you test the Lord?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people thirsted there for water, and the people complained against Moses and said, “Why did you bring us out of Egypt, to kill us and our children and livestock with thirst?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses cried out to the Lord, “What shall I do for this people? They are almost ready to stone me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Go on ahead of the people and take some of the elders of Israel with you; take in your hand the staff with which you struck the Nile and go.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will be standing there in front of you on the rock at Horeb. Strike the rock, and water will come out of it, so that the people may drink.” Moses did so, in the sight of the elders of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He called the place Massah and Meribah, because the Israelites quarreled and tested the Lord, saying, “Is the Lord among us or not?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Amalek came and fought with Israel at Rephidim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Joshua, “Choose some men for us and go out; fight with Amalek. Tomorrow I will stand on the top of the hill with the staff of God in my hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua did as Moses told him and fought with Amalek, while Moses, Aaron, and Hur went up to the top of the hill.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever Moses held up his hand, Israel prevailed, and whenever he lowered his hand, Amalek prevailed.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses’s hands grew heavy, so they took a stone and put it under him, and he sat on it. Aaron and Hur held up his hands, one on either side, so his hands were steady until the sun set.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Joshua defeated Amalek and his people with the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Write this as a remembrance in a book and recite it in the hearing of Joshua: I will utterly blot out the memory of Amalek from under heaven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses built an altar and called it, The Lord is my banner.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “A hand upon the banner of the Lord! The Lord will have war with Amalek from generation to generation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jethro, the priest of Midian, Moses’s father-in-law, heard of all that God had done for Moses and for his people Israel, how the Lord had brought Israel out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Moses had sent away his wife Zipporah, his father-in-law Jethro took her back,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with her two sons. The name of the one was Gershom (for he had said, “I have been an alien in a foreign land”),
speaker: Narrator

text: and the name of the other was Eliezer (for he had said, “The God of my father was my help and delivered me from the sword of Pharaoh”).
speaker: Narrator

text: Jethro, Moses’s father-in-law, along with Moses’s sons and wife, came into the wilderness where Moses was encamped at the mountain of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent word to Moses, “I, your father-in-law Jethro, am coming to you, with your wife and her two sons.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses went out to meet his father-in-law; he bowed down and kissed him; each asked after the other’s welfare, and they went into the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses told his father-in-law all that the Lord had done to Pharaoh and to the Egyptians for Israel’s sake, all the hardship that had found them on the way, and how the Lord had delivered them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jethro rejoiced for all the good that the Lord had done to Israel, in delivering them from the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jethro said, “Blessed be the Lord, who has delivered you from the Egyptians and from Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I know that the Lord is greater than all gods, because he delivered the people from the Egyptians, when they dealt arrogantly with them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jethro, Moses’s father-in-law, brought a burnt offering and sacrifices to God, and Aaron came with all the elders of Israel to eat bread with Moses’s father-in-law in the presence of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day Moses sat as judge for the people, while the people stood around him from morning until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses’s father-in-law saw all that he was doing for the people, he said, “What is this that you are doing for the people? Why do you sit alone, while all the people stand around you from morning until evening?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to his father-in-law, “Because the people come to me to inquire of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they have a dispute, they come to me, and I decide between one person and another, and I make known to them the statutes and instructions of God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses’s father-in-law said to him, “What you are doing is not good.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will surely wear yourself out, both you and these people with you, for the task is too heavy for you; you cannot do it alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now listen to me. I will give you counsel, and God be with you! You should represent the people before God and bring their cases to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Teach them the statutes and instructions and make known to them the way they are to go and the things they are to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: You should also look for able men among all the people, men who fear God, are trustworthy, and hate dishonest gain; set them as officers over thousands, hundreds, fifties, and tens.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let them sit as judges for the people at all times; let them bring every important case to you but decide every minor case themselves. So it will be easier for you, and they will bear the burden with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do this and God so commands you, then you will be able to endure, and all these people will go to their homes in peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses listened to his father-in-law and did all that he had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses chose able men from all Israel and appointed them as heads over the people, as officers over thousands, hundreds, fifties, and tens.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they judged the people at all times; hard cases they brought to Moses, but any minor case they decided themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses let his father-in-law depart, and he went off to his own country.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third new moon after the Israelites had gone out of the land of Egypt, on that very day, they came into the wilderness of Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: They journeyed from Rephidim, entered the wilderness of Sinai, and camped in the wilderness; Israel camped there in front of the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses went up to God; the Lord called to him from the mountain, “Thus you shall say to the house of Jacob and tell the Israelites:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You have seen what I did to the Egyptians and how I bore you on eagles’ wings and brought you to myself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, therefore, if you obey my voice and keep my covenant, you shall be my treasured possession out of all the peoples. Indeed, the whole earth is mine,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you shall be for me a priestly kingdom and a holy nation.’ These are the words that you shall speak to the Israelites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses went, summoned the elders of the people, and set before them all these words that the Lord had commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people all answered as one, “Everything that the Lord has spoken we will do.” Moses reported the words of the people to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Lord said to Moses, “I am going to come to you in a dense cloud, in order that the people may hear when I speak with you and so trust you ever after.”
When Moses had told the words of the people to the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord said to Moses, “Go to the people and consecrate them today and tomorrow. Have them wash their clothes
speaker: Narrator

text: and prepare for the third day, because on the third day the Lord will come down upon Mount Sinai in the sight of all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall set limits for the people all around, saying, ‘Be careful not to go up the mountain or to touch the edge of it. Any who touch the mountain shall be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: No hand shall touch them, but they shall be stoned or shot with arrows; whether animal or human being, they shall not live.’ When the trumpet sounds a long blast, they may go up on the mountain.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses went down from the mountain to the people. He consecrated the people, and they washed their clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to the people, “Prepare for the third day; do not go near a woman.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the morning of the third day there was thunder and lightning, as well as a thick cloud on the mountain and a blast of a trumpet so loud that all the people who were in the camp trembled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses brought the people out of the camp to meet God. They took their stand at the foot of the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now all of Mount Sinai was wrapped in smoke, because the Lord had descended upon it in fire; the smoke went up like the smoke of a kiln, while the whole mountain shook violently.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the blast of the trumpet grew louder and louder, Moses would speak and God would answer him in thunder.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord descended upon Mount Sinai, to the top of the mountain, the Lord summoned Moses to the top of the mountain, and Moses went up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go down and warn the people not to break through to see the Lord; otherwise many of them will perish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even the priests who approach the Lord must consecrate themselves, or the Lord will break out against them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the Lord, “The people are not permitted to come up to Mount Sinai, for you yourself warned us, saying, ‘Set limits around the mountain and keep it holy.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to him, “Go down, then come back up and bring Aaron with you, but do not let either the priests or the people break through to come up to the Lord; otherwise he will break out against them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses went down to the people and told them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God spoke all these words,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of slavery;
speaker: Narrator

text: you shall have no other gods before me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not make for yourself an idol, whether in the form of anything that is in heaven above or that is on the earth beneath or that is in the water under the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall not bow down to them or serve them, for I the Lord your God am a jealous God, punishing children for the iniquity of parents to the third and the fourth generation of those who reject me
speaker: Narrator

text: but showing steadfast love to the thousandth generation of those who love me and keep my commandments.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not make wrongful use of the name of the Lord your God, for the Lord will not acquit anyone who misuses his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Remember the Sabbath day and keep it holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Six days you shall labor and do all your work.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the seventh day is a Sabbath to the Lord your God; you shall not do any work—you, your son or your daughter, your male or female slave, your livestock, or the alien resident in your towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in six days the Lord made heaven and earth, the sea, and all that is in them, but rested the seventh day; therefore the Lord blessed the Sabbath day and consecrated it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Honor your father and your mother, so that your days may be long in the land that the Lord your God is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not murder.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not commit adultery.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not steal.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not bear false witness against your neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not covet your neighbor’s house; you shall not covet your neighbor’s wife, male or female slave, ox, donkey, or anything that belongs to your neighbor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the people witnessed the thunder and lightning, the sound of the trumpet, and the mountain smoking, they were afraid and trembled and stood at a distance
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to Moses, “You speak to us, and we will listen, but do not let God speak to us, lest we die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the people, “Do not be afraid, for God has come only to test you and to put the fear of him upon you so that you do not sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people stood at a distance, while Moses drew near to the thick darkness where God was.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Thus you shall say to the Israelites: You have seen for yourselves how I spoke with you from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall not make gods of silver alongside me, nor shall you make for yourselves gods of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: You need make for me only an altar of earth and sacrifice on it your burnt offerings and your offerings of well-being, your sheep and your oxen; in every place where I cause my name to be remembered I will come to you and bless you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you make for me an altar of stone, do not build it of hewn stones, for if you use a chisel upon it you profane it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall not go up by steps to my altar, so that your nakedness may not be exposed on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the ordinances that you shall set before them:
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you buy a male Hebrew slave, he shall serve six years, but in the seventh he shall go out a free person, without debt.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he comes in single, he shall go out single; if he comes in married, then his wife shall go out with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: If his master gives him a wife and she bears him sons or daughters, the wife and her children shall be her master’s, and he shall go out alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the slave declares, ‘I love my master, my wife, and my children; I will not go out a free person,’
speaker: Narrator

text: then his master shall bring him before God. He shall be brought to the door or the doorpost, and his master shall pierce his ear with an awl, and he shall serve him for life.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a man sells his daughter as a slave, she shall not go out as the male slaves do.
speaker: Narrator

text: If she does not please her master, who designated her for himself, then he shall let her be redeemed; he shall have no right to sell her to a foreign people, since he has dealt unfairly with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he designates her for his son, he shall deal with her as with a daughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he takes another wife to himself, he shall not diminish the food, clothing, or marital rights of the first wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if he does not do these three things for her, she shall go out without debt, without payment of money.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever strikes a person mortally shall be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it was not premeditated but came about by an act of God, then I will appoint for you a place to which the killer may flee.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if someone willfully attacks and kills another by treachery, you shall take the killer from my altar for execution.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever strikes father or mother shall be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever kidnaps a person, whether that person has been sold or is still held in possession, shall be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever curses father or mother shall be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When individuals quarrel and one strikes the other with a stone or fist so that the injured party, though not dead, is confined to bed
speaker: Narrator

text: but recovers and walks around outside with the help of a staff, then the assailant shall be free of liability, except to pay for the loss of time and to arrange for full recovery.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a slaveowner strikes a male or female slave with a rod and the slave dies immediately, the owner shall be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the slave survives a day or two, there is no punishment, for the slave is the owner’s property.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When people who are fighting injure a pregnant woman so that there is a miscarriage and yet no further harm follows, the one responsible shall be fined what the woman’s husband demands, paying as much as the judges determine.
speaker: Narrator

text: If any harm follows, then you shall give life for life,
speaker: Narrator

text: eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot,
speaker: Narrator

text: burn for burn, wound for wound, stripe for stripe.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a slaveowner strikes the eye of a male or female slave, destroying it, the owner shall let the slave go, a free person, to compensate for the eye.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the owner knocks out a tooth of a male or female slave, the slave shall be let go, a free person, to compensate for the tooth.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When an ox gores a man or a woman to death, the ox shall be stoned, and its flesh shall not be eaten, but the owner of the ox shall not be liable.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the ox has been accustomed to gore in the past and its owner has been warned but did not restrain it, and it kills a man or a woman, the ox shall be stoned, and its owner also shall be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a ransom is imposed on the owner, then the owner shall pay whatever is imposed for the redemption of the victim’s life.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it gores a boy or a girl, the owner shall be dealt with according to this same rule.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the ox gores a male or female slave, the owner shall pay to the slaveowner thirty shekels of silver, and the ox shall be stoned.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If someone leaves a pit open or digs a pit and does not cover it, and an ox or a donkey falls into it,
speaker: Narrator

text: the owner of the pit shall make restitution, giving money to its owner but keeping the dead animal.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If someone’s ox hurts the ox of another, so that it dies, then they shall sell the live ox and divide the price of it, and the dead animal they shall also divide.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if it was known that the ox was accustomed to gore in the past and its owner did not restrain it, the owner shall restore ox for ox but keep the dead animal.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When someone steals an ox or a sheep and slaughters it or sells it, the thief shall pay five oxen for an ox and four sheep for a sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: (If the thief is found breaking in and is struck dead, no bloodguilt is incurred;
speaker: Narrator

text: but if it happens after sunrise, bloodguilt is incurred.) The thief shall make full restitution or, if unable to do so, shall be sold for the theft.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the animal, whether ox or donkey or sheep, is found alive in the thief’s possession, the thief shall pay double.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When someone causes a field or vineyard to be grazed over or lets livestock loose to graze in someone else’s field, restitution shall be made from the best in the owner’s field or vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When fire breaks out and catches in thorns so that the stacked grain or the standing grain or the field is consumed, the one who started the fire shall make full restitution.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When someone delivers to a neighbor money or goods for safekeeping and they are stolen from the neighbor’s house, then the thief, if caught, shall pay double.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the thief is not caught, the owner of the house shall be brought before God, to determine whether or not the owner had laid hands on the neighbor’s goods.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In any case of disputed ownership involving ox, donkey, sheep, clothing, or any other loss, of which one party says, ‘This is mine,’ the case of both parties shall come before God; the one whom God condemns shall pay double to the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When someone delivers to another a donkey, ox, sheep, or any other animal for safekeeping and it dies or is injured or is carried off without anyone seeing it,
speaker: Narrator

text: an oath before the Lord shall decide between the two of them that the one has not laid hands on the property of the other; the owner shall accept the oath, and no restitution shall be made.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if it was stolen, restitution shall be made to its owner.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it was mangled by beasts, let it be brought as evidence; restitution shall not be made for the mangled remains.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When someone borrows an animal from another and it is injured or dies, the owner not being present, full restitution shall be made.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the owner was present, there shall be no restitution; if it was hired, only the hiring fee is due.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a man seduces a virgin who is not engaged to be married and lies with her, he shall give the bride-price for her and make her his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if her father refuses to give her to him, he shall pay an amount equal to the bride-price for virgins.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not permit a female sorcerer to live.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever has intercourse with an animal shall be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever sacrifices to any god other than the Lord alone shall be devoted to destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not wrong or oppress a resident alien, for you were aliens in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall not abuse any widow or orphan.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do abuse them, when they cry out to me, I will surely heed their cry;
speaker: Narrator

text: my wrath will burn, and I will kill you with the sword, and your wives shall become widows and your children orphans.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you lend money to my people, to the poor among you, you shall not deal with them as a creditor; you shall not exact interest from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you take your neighbor’s cloak as guarantee, you shall restore it before the sun goes down,
speaker: Narrator

text: for it may be your neighbor’s only clothing to use as a cover. In what else shall that person sleep? And when your neighbor cries out to me, I will listen, for I am compassionate.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not revile God or curse a leader of your people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You shall not delay to make offerings from the fullness of your harvest and from the outflow of your presses.
“The firstborn of your sons you shall give to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall do the same with your oxen and with your sheep: seven days it shall remain with its mother; on the eighth day you shall give it to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall be people consecrated to me, so you shall not eat any meat that is mangled by beasts in the field; you shall throw it to the dogs.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not spread a false report. You shall not join hands with the wicked to act as a malicious witness.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall not follow a majority in wrongdoing; when you bear witness in a lawsuit, you shall not side with the majority so as to pervert justice,
speaker: Narrator

text: nor shall you be partial to the poor in a lawsuit.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you come upon your enemy’s ox or donkey going astray, you shall bring it back.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you see the donkey of one who hates you struggling under its burden and you would hold back from setting it free, you must help to set it free.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not pervert the justice due to your poor in their lawsuits.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep far from a false charge, and do not kill the innocent and those in the right, for I will not acquit the guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall take no bribe, for a bribe blinds officials and subverts the cause of those who are in the right.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not oppress a resident alien; you know the heart of an alien, for you were aliens in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Six years you shall sow your land and gather in its yield,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the seventh year you shall let it rest and lie fallow so that the poor of your people may eat, and what they leave the wild animals may eat. You shall do the same with your vineyard and with your olive orchard.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Six days you shall do your work, but on the seventh day you shall rest so that your ox and your donkey may have relief and your homeborn slave and the resident alien may be refreshed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be attentive to all that I have said to you. Do not invoke the names of other gods; do not let them be heard on your lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Three times in the year you shall hold a festival for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You shall observe the Festival of Unleavened Bread; as I commanded you, you shall eat unleavened bread for seven days at the appointed time in the month of Abib, for in it you came out of Egypt.
“No one shall appear before me empty-handed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall observe the Festival of Harvest, of the first fruits of your labor, of what you sow in the field. You shall observe the Festival of Ingathering at the end of the year, when you gather in from the field the fruit of your labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three times in the year all your males shall appear before the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not offer the blood of my sacrifice with anything leavened or let the fat of my festival remain until the morning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The choicest of the first fruits of your ground you shall bring into the house of the Lord your God.
“You shall not boil a kid in its mother’s milk.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am going to send an angel in front of you, to guard you on the way and to bring you to the place that I have prepared.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be attentive to him and listen to his voice; do not rebel against him, for he will not pardon your transgression, for my name is in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if you listen attentively to his voice and do all that I say, then I will be an enemy to your enemies and a foe to your foes.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When my angel goes in front of you and brings you to the Amorites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Canaanites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites, and I blot them out,
speaker: Narrator

text: you shall not bow down to their gods or serve them or follow their practices, but you shall utterly demolish them and break their pillars in pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall serve the Lord your God, and I will bless your bread and your water, and I will take sickness away from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one shall miscarry or be barren in your land; I will fulfill the number of your days.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will send my terror in front of you and will throw into confusion all the people against whom you shall come, and I will make all your enemies turn their backs to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will send swarms of hornets in front of you, which shall drive out the Hivites, the Canaanites, and the Hittites from before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will not drive them out from before you in one year, lest the land become desolate and the wild animals multiply against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Little by little I will drive them out from before you, until you have increased and possess the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will set your borders from the Red Sea to the sea of the Philistines and from the wilderness to the Euphrates, for I will hand over to you the inhabitants of the land, and you shall drive them out before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall make no covenant with them and their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall not live in your land, lest they make you sin against me, for if you serve their gods, it will surely be a snare to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to Moses, “Come up to the Lord, you and Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel, and worship at a distance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses alone shall come near the Lord, but the others shall not come near, and the people shall not come up with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses went and told the people all the words of the Lord and all the ordinances, and all the people answered with one voice and said, “All the words that the Lord has spoken we will do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses wrote down all the words of the Lord. He rose early in the morning, built an altar at the foot of the mountain, and set up twelve pillars, corresponding to the twelve tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent young men of the Israelites, who offered burnt offerings and sacrificed oxen as offerings of well-being to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses took half of the blood and put it in basins, and half of the blood he dashed against the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took the book of the covenant and read it in the hearing of the people, and they said, “All that the Lord has spoken we will do, and we will be obedient.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses took the blood and dashed it on the people, and said, “Here is the blood of the covenant that the Lord has made with you in accordance with all these words.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel went up,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they saw the God of Israel. Under his feet there was something like a pavement of sapphire stone, like the very heaven for clearness.
speaker: Narrator

text: God did not lay his hand on the chief men of the Israelites; they beheld God, and they ate and drank.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Come up to me on the mountain and wait there; I will give you the tablets of stone, with the law and the commandment, which I have written for their instruction.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses set out with his assistant Joshua, and Moses went up onto the mountain of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: To the elders he had said, “Wait here for us, until we come back to you. Look, Aaron and Hur are with you; whoever has a dispute may go to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses went up on the mountain, and the cloud covered the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: The glory of the Lord settled on Mount Sinai, and the cloud covered it for six days; on the seventh day he called to Moses out of the cloud.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the appearance of the glory of the Lord was like a devouring fire on the top of the mountain in the sight of the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses entered the cloud and went up on the mountain. Moses was on the mountain for forty days and forty nights.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites to take for me an offering; from all whose hearts prompt them to give you shall receive the offering for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the offering that you shall receive from them: gold, silver, and bronze,
speaker: Narrator

text: blue, purple, and crimson yarns and fine linen, goats’ hair,
speaker: Narrator

text: tanned rams’ skins, fine leather, acacia wood,
speaker: Narrator

text: oil for the lamps, spices for the anointing oil and for the fragrant incense,
speaker: Narrator

text: onyx stones and gems to be set in the ephod and for the breastpiece.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they shall make me a sanctuary so that I may dwell among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: In accordance with all that I show you concerning the pattern of the tabernacle and of all its furniture, so you shall make it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They shall make an ark of acacia wood; it shall be two and a half cubits long, a cubit and a half wide, and a cubit and a half high.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall overlay it with pure gold, inside and outside you shall overlay it, and you shall make a molding of gold upon it all around.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall cast four rings of gold for it and put them on its four feet, two rings on one side of it and two rings on the other side.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall make poles of acacia wood and overlay them with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you shall put the poles into the rings on the sides of the ark, for carrying the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: The poles shall remain in the rings of the ark; they shall not be removed.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall put the covenant that I am giving you into the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then you shall make a cover of pure gold; two cubits and a half shall be its length and a cubit and a half its width.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall make two cherubim of gold; you shall make them of hammered work at the two ends of the cover.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make one cherub at one end and one cherub at the other; of one piece with the cover you shall make the cherubim at its two ends.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cherubim shall spread out their wings above, overshadowing the cover with their wings. They shall face one to another; the faces of the cherubim shall be turned toward the cover.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall put the cover on the top of the ark, and in the ark you shall put the covenant that I am giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: There I will meet with you, and from above the cover, from between the two cherubim that are on the ark of the covenant, I will tell you all that I am commanding you for the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall make a table of acacia wood, two cubits long, one cubit wide, and a cubit and a half high.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall overlay it with pure gold and make a molding of gold around it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall make around it a rim a handbreadth wide and a molding of gold around the rim.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall make for it four rings of gold and fasten the rings to the four corners at its four legs.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rings that hold the poles used for carrying the table shall be close to the rim.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall make the poles of acacia wood and overlay them with gold, and the table shall be carried with these.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall make its plates and dishes and its flagons and bowls with which to pour drink offerings; you shall make them of pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you shall set the bread of the Presence on the table before me continually.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall make a lampstand of pure gold. The base and the shaft of the lampstand shall be made of hammered work; its cups, its calyxes, and its petals shall be of one piece with it;
speaker: Narrator

text: and there shall be six branches going out of its sides: three branches of the lampstand out of one side of it and three branches of the lampstand out of the other side of it;
speaker: Narrator

text: three cups shaped like almond blossoms, each with calyx and petals, on one branch, and three cups shaped like almond blossoms, each with calyx and petals, on the other branch—so for the six branches going out of the lampstand.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the lampstand itself there shall be four cups shaped like almond blossoms, each with its calyxes and petals.
speaker: Narrator

text: There shall be a calyx of one piece with it under the first pair of branches, a calyx of one piece with it under the next pair of branches, and a calyx of one piece with it under the last pair of branches—so for the six branches that go out of the lampstand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their calyxes and their branches shall be of one piece with it, the whole of it one hammered piece of pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall make seven lamps for it, and the lamps shall be set up so as to give light on the space in front of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its snuffers and trays shall be of pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: It and all these utensils shall be made from a talent of pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: And see that you make them according to the pattern for them, which is being shown you on the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The tabernacle itself you shall make with ten curtains of fine twisted linen and blue, purple, and crimson yarns; you shall make them with cherubim skillfully worked into them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The length of each curtain shall be twenty-eight cubits and the width of each curtain four cubits; all the curtains shall be of the same size.
speaker: Narrator

text: Five curtains shall be joined to one another, and the other five curtains shall be joined to one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall make loops of blue on the edge of the outermost curtain in the first set, and likewise you shall make loops on the edge of the outermost curtain in the second set.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall make fifty loops on the one curtain, and you shall make fifty loops on the edge of the curtain that is in the second set; the loops shall be opposite one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall make fifty clasps of gold and join the curtains to one another with the clasps, so that the tabernacle may be one whole.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall also make curtains of goats’ hair for a tent over the tabernacle; you shall make eleven curtains.
speaker: Narrator

text: The length of each curtain shall be thirty cubits and the width of each curtain four cubits; the eleven curtains shall be of the same size.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall join five curtains by themselves and six curtains by themselves, and the sixth curtain you shall double over at the front of the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall make fifty loops on the edge of the curtain that is outermost in one set and fifty loops on the edge of the curtain that is outermost in the second set.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall make fifty clasps of bronze and put the clasps into the loops and join the tent together, so that it may be one whole.
speaker: Narrator

text: The part that remains of the curtains of the tent, the half curtain that remains, shall hang over the back of the tabernacle.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cubit on one side and the cubit on the other side of what remains in the length of the curtains of the tent shall hang over the sides of the tabernacle, on this side and that side, to cover it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall make for the tent a covering of tanned rams’ skins and an outer covering of fine leather.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall make upright frames of acacia wood for the tabernacle.
speaker: Narrator
